item.title: Publications
item.description:
ResearcherID E-2439-2012. You can also find me on ResearchGate and GoogleScholar.

in press - 2018 - 2017 - 2016 - 2015 - 2014 - 2013 - 2012 - pre 2012 - submitted

Lab alumni

Research assistants

  • 2017-2018 – Katarina Varga (M.Sc) – WSL, SCODA project (SNF) – ornithologist, bird territory mapping Switzerland
  • 2015 – Helge Gross – Uni Potsdam and WSL – data management, habitat selection in white storks
  • 2015 – Lena Schlag – Uni Potsdam and WSL – home range selection in white storks
  • 2014-2015 – Merlin Schäfer – Uni Potsdam and WSL – computer scientist, optimal annual routine models for migratory animals

Master

  • 2013-2014 – Andreas Neumann – “Vorhersage von Artenvielfalt und -zusammensetzung mittels überlagerter Artverbreitungsmodelle (S-SDM)” – Diplom, Uni Potsdam, main Supervisor: Dr. Anna Cord (UFZ Leipzig)
  • 2013-2014 – Helge Gross – “Multi-regional assessment of determinants of tree species diversity in Mexico” – Diplom, Uni Potsdam , main Supervisor: Dr. Anna Cord (UFZ Leipzig)
  • 2013-2014 – Merlin Schäfer – “Modeling of optimal annual routines to infer migration timing in white storks (Ciconia ciconia)” – M.Sc., Technische Universität Berlin
  • 2013-2014 – Alexandra Hinz – “Dynamic patterns of behaviour in breeding white storks (Ciconia ciconia): an analysis using 3-dimensional acceleration data” – M.Sc., Uni Potsdam

Interns

  • 2014 – Ruben Ulbrich – “Species distribution modelling of invasive species using presence-only data” – Intern, University of Namibia
  • 2013 – Marianne Meinel – “Validation of flight behaviour and wing beat frequency from ACC signal by video surveillance” – Intern, Uni Potsdam
  • 2013 – Simon Wohlfahrt – field assistant, GPS tracking white storks, ACC behavioural observations – Intern, Uni Potsdam

item.title: Damaris Zurell
item.description:
Contact - Education - Career - Projects - Awards - Professional activities - Memberships

Contact details

Dr. Damaris Zurell

Geography Department | Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin

Unter den Linden 6 | D-10099 Berlin | Germany

Office: Rudower Chaussee 16 | D-12489 Berlin | Room 1.208

Phone: +49 30 2093 6869

My institutional website

Education

  • 2011 – PhD in Geoecology, University of Potsdam, Inst. of Earth and Environmental Sciences

  • 2007 – Diplom (M.Sc.) in Geoecology, University of Potsdam, Inst. of Geoecology

Career

  • since 2018 – Emmy Noether reseach group leader, Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin, Geography Department

  • 2016 - 2018 – Scientific staff member, Swiss Federal Research Institute WSL, Dept. Landscape Dynamics

  • 2014 - 2016 – Postdoc, Swiss Federal Research Institute WSL, Dept. Landscape Dynamics

  • 2011 - 2014 – PostDoc, University of Potsdam, Inst. for Biochemistry and Biology

Projects
  • 2018-2020 – Interdisciplinary project funded by Swiss Data Science Center SDSC, “SPEEDMIND - Improving species biodiversity analyses and citizen science feedback through mining data” (WSL share CHF 200’000, Damaris is co-PI)
  • 2018-2023 – DFG Emmy Noether junior research group, “BIOPIC – Disentangling the effects of demography, dispersal and biotic interactions in population and community response to global change” (€ 1’007’919)
  • 2016-2019 – SNF Ambizione Fellowship, “SCODA – Scaling from individual interactions to community dynamics in avian assemblages” (CHF 492’204)
  • 2014-2016 – EU-FP7 Marie Curie Intra-European Fellowship (IEF), “MATES – Understanding and predicting multispecies assemblages and interactions in space and time” (€ 208’000)
  • 2014 – University of Potsdam Individual Postdoc Grant “Bridge Programme” (€ 8’250)
  • 2007-2010 – PhD Scholarship by the Potsdam Graduate School on Ecological Modelling UPGradE (€ 45’600)
Awards
  • 2012 – Junior Scientist publication award by Leibniz-Kolleg Potsdam, Germany (€ 1’250)
  • 2008 – Junior Scientist Award by the Federal State of Brandenburg, Germany, Category Graduates (€ 5’000)
  • 2008 – Jacob-Jacobi Award (best degree of the academic year) by the Faculty of Mathematics and Natural Sciences, University of Potsdam, Germany (€ 500)
  • 2007 – Diplom/ Master Award by the Ecological Society of Germany, Austria and Switzerland (GfÖ) (€ 2’500)
Professional activities
Editorial board
  • Diversity and Distributions - Associate editor since June 2016
Journal reviewing
  • American Naturalist, Basic and Applied Ecology, Diversity and Distributions, Ecography, Ecological Modelling, Ecosphere, Environmental Modelling & Software, Global Change Biology, Global Ecology and Biogeography, Journal of Applied Ecology, Journal of Biogeography, Journal of Ornithology, Journal of the Royal Society Interface, Methods in Ecology and Evolution, Oikos, PeerJ, Theoretical Ecology
  • Natur und Landschaft
Organisation of meetings
  • 2018 – co-organisation of 3-day international workshop “Macroecology in the age of big data”, annual meeting of the GfÖ specialist group “Macroecology”, Birmensdorf, Switzerland
  • 2015 – co-organisation of 5-day international research workshop “Biotic interactions across space and time”, Akademie Waldschlösschen, Germany (participation upon invitation only)
  • 2011 – co-organisation of symposium “Towards rules of thumb for predictions of range dynamics” at annual conference of GfÖ, Oldenburg, Germany
  • 2009 – co-organisation of 3-day international workshop “Process-based modelling meets macroecological patterns”, joint annual meeting of the GfÖ specialist groups “Theory in Ecology” and “Macroecology”, Potsdam, Germany
  • 2008 – co-organisation of symposium “Macroecology and climate change – Past, present and future” during joint annual conference of European Ecological Federation (EURECO) and Ecological Society of Germany, Austria and Switzerland (GfÖ) in Leipzig, Germany
Memberships

Ecological Society of Germany, Switzerland and Austria (GfÖ) International Biogeography Society (IBS)

item.title: Downloads
item.description:
You can download some of my codes from my github site.

Repository IBM_OptimalForaging

C++ codes for individual-based foraging model described in Zurell et al. (2015) Oikos.

Repository Rcodes_MapNovelEnvironments_SDMs

R codes for mapping novel environments (SDM inflated response curves and environmental overlap masks) described in Zurell et al. (2012) DDI.

item.title: Join the lab
item.description:
Job openings, Bachelor and Master theses …

Job openings – Funding opportunities – Thesis topics

If you would like to do a postdoc, PhD, Master or Bachelor with me, please do not hesitate to contact me. Some topics and anticipated job openings are listed below, but own ideas are always welcome and I am happy to discuss funding possibilities.

Job openings

There are no current job openings.

Funding opportunities for postdoc or PhD work

I am happy to discuss funding opportunities for individual postdoc or PhD projects.

To get a first overview, here are some links to funding bodies.

For students/postdocs currently based outside Germany:

  • DAAD – The German Academic Exchange Service provides a PhD/Postdoc scholarship data base.
  • AvH – The Alexander-von-Humboldt foundation offers different postdoctoral fellowships to come to Germany.
  • Einstein – The Einstein Foundation offers special postdoctoral fellowships for Berlin-based working groups.
  • Elsa-Neumann – The city of Berlin offers PhD scholarships.
  • DFG – The German Science Foundation offers various research grants.
  • H2020 – The EU offers individual postdoctoral fellowships within the Marie Skłodowska-Curie actions.

For students/postdocs currently based in Germany:

  • DFG – The German Science Foundation offers various research grants.
  • DBU – The German Federal Environmental Foundation offers PhD scholarships.
  • Elsa-Neumann – The city of Berlin offers PhD scholarships.

Bachelor and Master theses

Here are some potential thesis topics. Also own suggestions are welcome. Please regard the attributes Master and Bachelor thesis as a suggestion - topics, scope and tasks are negotiable and up to your creativity. I also indicate the skills you will acquire during the thesis - previous knowledge is welcome but not mandatory.

Bachelor/Master thesis: Ecosystem functions provided by animals and potential disruptions under global change

Animals provide important ecosystem functions to each other. For example, ants and birds disperse seeds and nutrients, and (wild)bees and butterflies pollinate plants. Some of these mutualistic interactions may be highly specialised, for example when one plant species is only pollinated by one insect species, other interactions may be more generalistic. Here, we will compile a list of important ecosystem functions by animals, and assess the vulnerability of these under global environmental change.

  • Skills learned: Literature search, meta-analyses, species distribution modelling
Master thesis: Life history strategies in birds: traits as proxy of intra- and interspecific interactions

Life history emerges from natural selection. Individuals have to trade-off costs and benefits of specific actions, how much they invest in reproduction, survival, maintenance and defence. Here, we will analyse correlations between life-history traits in birds (e.g. body size, clutch size, diet) and their competitive behaviours towards conspecifics and heterospecifics. This will help us to better understand how trait syndromes may mediate interspecific interactions. We will analyse Swiss breeding birds for which we already have extensive data on foraging and habitat traits available. These trait data will be extended by information on territorial/competitive behaviours that will be obtained from literature research.

  • Skills learned: R programming, statistical analyses, trait analyses
Master thesis: Improving winter occurrence data for migratory birds

Migratory birds use distant habitats during breeding and overwintering. Existing range maps on wintering habitats are usually less accurate than the range maps of the breeding season. Here, we will use citizen-science based occurrence records from eBird to improve distribution maps of migratory birds, focussing on long-distance migrants breeding in Europe and overwintering in Africa. Species distribution models will be estimated using range maps and using eBird data, and inference will be compared.

  • Skills learned: R programming, GIS analyses, species distribution modelling
Master thesis: Integrating consumer-resource interactions in bird species distribution models

Birds (and other animals) are not only influenced by abiotic conditions such as climate but also by the amount of available resources. Often, resources such as the favourite food plants are included in the models only indirectly through accounting for major habitat associations or correlations with climate. Here, we will build a hierarchical model in which the occurrence of the bird and the occurrence of its food plants is modelled simultaneously. This will allow disentangling the abiotic effects on food plants from the abiotic effects on consumer survival. I would suggest using black grouse as study species, but this is not mandatory.

  • Skills learned: R programming, GIS analyses, species distribution modelling, Bayesian statistics
